fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We just have to verify that the two conversions are mutual inverses. In one way, we need to verify \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } M f \mathbin {\circ } \eta = f. This is true because by the naturality of \eta we get M f \mathbin {\circ } \eta = \eta \mathbin {\circ } f. Then by the definition of algebra \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } \eta = \textrm {id}, proving the equality. On the other hand, we need to show \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } M(\varphi \mathbin {\circ } \eta ) = \varphi . This follows from the algebra identity \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } M \alpha _Y = \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } \mu and the monad identity \mu \mathbin {\circ } M \eta = \textrm {id}.

Given a monad M on a category \mathcal {C}, there is a canonical adjunction between the category of algebras \mathcal {C}^M and \mathcal {C}. The forgetful functor U_M takes an algebra and forgets the algebra structure. The free functor F_M takes an object X and produces an algebra on MX given by the monad multiplication map \mu : M^2 X \to MX, called the free algebra.

We just have to verify that the two conversions are mutual inverses. In one way, we need to verify \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } M f \mathbin {\circ } \eta = f. This is true because by the naturality of \eta we get M f \mathbin {\circ } \eta = \eta \mathbin {\circ } f. Then by the definition of algebra \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } \eta = \textrm {id}, proving the equality. On the other hand, we need to show \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } M(\varphi \mathbin {\circ } \eta ) = \varphi . This follows from the algebra identity \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } M \alpha _Y = \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } \mu and the monad identity \mu \mathbin {\circ } M \eta = \textrm {id}.
